You\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdll carry out the same kind of work and gain the same kind of client exposure as our graduate recruits. As well as practical experience, you\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdll also get a flavour of what our graduate programme is really like. Your application form will be based on the one we use for our graduate programme, and you\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdll go through exactly the same assessment and interview process. You\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdll even attend the same induction with the graduates. There will also be a dedicated event for you to network and make contacts. We have vacancies for graduates from IT/computing backgrounds in a number of practice areas across the UK. For more information see our website.

Main website: www.cgg.com Twitter: @CGGcompany Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/CGG MyCareers: Search for roles with CGG on MyCareers ]]> No publisher ks53 Festival of Careers Fairs Postgraduate College:Arts Geology Finalist College:SciEng FOC Wednesday Second Year Employers Interns College:MedBioPsych Engineering Mathematics College:SocSci Physics 2014-07-01T14:55:00Z Page Camera obscurer: How the Doppler Effect could get you out of a speeding ticket https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/march/camera-obscurer-how-the-doppler-effect-could-get-you-out-of-a-speeding-ticket Physics and Astronomy students find it would be possible to become invisible to speed cameras \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd if you could travel at a sixth of the speed of light Our physics students are a cunning bunch. In a paper for this year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Journal of Physics Special Topics, a group of four MPhys students from the Department of Physics and Astronomy\ufffd\ufffdworked out how you could avoid getting a speeding ticket - by driving so fast your car would become invisible to speed cameras.

It\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds all down to the Doppler Effect \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the physical phenomenon which allows light from an object to be \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdshifted\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd upwards or downwards along the spectrum as the object moves to or from an observer.

According to the well-trodden formula astronomers use for working out the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdred shift\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd of stars, you could theoretically drive fast enough for your number plate to be shifted out of the visible spectrum, rendering it undetectable to even the most beady-eyed of yellow boxes.

But the paper\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds authors - students Dan Worthy, Robert Garner, Jenny Gregory and Jessica Taylor-Ashley - are certainly not recommending you try out this dangerous and highly-illegal tactic for yourself.

Besides, it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds going to be a little while before we\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdve developed anything that could reach the necessary speeds. According to their calculations, you would have to be going at 119 million miles per hour to shift the yellow light of the number plate from its usual frequency at 515 terahertz to its required value at less than 400 terahertz, the boundary of visible light.

That\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds a sixth of the speed of light \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd almost 800 times faster than the quickest man-made vehicle of all time, the Helios Probe.

In other words, it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds still best to stick to the speed limit - for all concerned.

The Journal of Physics Special Topics is a peer-reviewed student journal run by our Department of Physics and Astronomy.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy Physics Magazine:Research Magazine:Student 2014-03-21T10:53:52Z Blog Entry Ancient Egyptian Astronomy https://www2.le.ac.uk/Members/sls25/index The homepage of Sarah Symons Papers

My most recent paper, which is a re-appraisal of diagonal star tables (or "star clocks") is available here:

A Star\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Year: The Annual Cycle in the Ancient Egyptian Sky

Courses

I give talks, workshops, and study weekends on Egyptian astronomy and also hieroglyphics.\ufffd\ufffd I teach an undergraduate module on archaeoastronomy in the Interdisciplinary Science degree programme.

Contacts

E-mail me

]]> No publisher sls25 Astronomy Physics Archaeology 2008-07-17T09:33:28Z Page An (inter)stellar line-up for Stargazing LIVE 2014 https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/december/an-inter-stellar-line-up-for-stargazing-live-2014 An evening dedicated to the wonders and mysteries of the universe on Wednesday 8 January 2014 If you ever wondered where all our stars came from, what an alien would actually look like or what it is like to explore the surface of Mars, now is a good time to find out!

The University is once again hosting Stargazing LIVE:\ufffd\ufffda night of talks and activities dedicated to all things astronomical. The event forms part of the BBC's national Stargazing series, which begins in January.

The event at the University is taking place on Wednesday 8 January 2014.\ufffd\ufffdIt will kick off at 4:00pm with talks and interactive activities particularly suitable for younger astronomers and their families, then at 6:00pm begins a vast array of events that will appeal to visitors of all ages.

The past year has seen Leicester scientists discover the possible ingredients for ancient life on Mars, evidence for a new kind of cosmic explosion, the kilonova, and create the most extensive catalogue of cosmic X-rays in existence.

There is\ufffd\ufffda veritable feast of\ufffd\ufffdengaging activities to take part in, including\ufffd\ufffdbuilding and launching a rocket, trying meteorite ice cream, learning about the size and scale of the solar system, and of course trying a little \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdstargazing\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: looking at the stars with enthusiasts from across the region (weather permitting!).

Click here to book tickets. They will be available until Monday 16 December 2013. Places are limited so book early to avoid disappointment!

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff Space Research Centre Magazine:Business Magazine:Research Magazine:Student Physics Space 2013-12-04T10:50:03Z Blog Entry Alumnus shortlisted for top sci-fi writing prize https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2015-archive-1/february/alumnus-shortlisted-for-top-sci-fi-writing-prize Latest novel by Geology graduate Rod Duncan is in the running for the Philip K Dick Award An alumnus and former staff member at the University is on the shortlist for one of world's most prestigious sci-fi writing prizes, the Philip K Dick Award.

The only British author on the shortlist, he has been nominated for his book The Bullet Catcher\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Daughter, part one of a series of at least three books which will form \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Fall of the Gas-lit Empire\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. It is set in a Victorianesque version of Leicester and Lincolnshire and events happen in the aftermath of a Luddite revolution that has reigned back technology.

In being nominated, Rod joins the company of influential science fiction authors such as William Gibson, Stephen Baxter and Richard Morgan.

Rod studied Mining Geology in the Department of Geology from 1980, graduating in 1983. He then worked in the Department of Physics for two years from 1986, managing a computer system for the ionospheric physics research group, returning on a few occasions since to give one-off classes on creative writing.

  • Read a feature and interview with Rod Duncan
  • Interview with Rod Duncan in the Leicester Mercury
  • The Bullet Catcher\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Daughter is published by Angry Robot Books and available online from high street book stores and can be ordered through the University Bookshop.
]]> No publisher pt91 Geology Alumni Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student Physics 2015-02-23T12:50:58Z Blog Entry A New View of the Hot and Energetic Universe https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/november/a-new-view-of-the-hot-and-energetic-universe ESA selects the science theme for its next large mission The University is collaborating with partners including the Science Programme Committee of the European Space Agency (ESA) for its next Large (L-class) mission.

The theme is "The Hot and Energetic Universe", and the mission, using an Advanced Telescope for High ENergy Astrophysics (ATHENA),\ufffd\ufffdis expected to be launched in 2028, with the power to address some of the most fundamental questions in modern astrophysics.\ufffd\ufffd

With the new mission, astronomers will measure the properties of galaxy clusters in the distant Universe, and map the physical characteristics of the largest structures known.

This\ufffd\ufffdwill dramatically advance\ufffd\ufffdour understanding of how these structures first assembled when the Universe was just two billion years old.

Plans for a mission like\ufffd\ufffdATHENA started in an international research meeting held at the University in July 1996, entitled "The Next Generation of X-ray Observatories". Since then Leicester astronomers and instrumentation scientists have been core members of an international effort working towards the ambitious goal of understanding the universe.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Student Astronomy Astrophysics Physics 2013-11-28T16:04:19Z Blog Entry A need for speed will drive you up the wall https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/march/A%20need%20for%20speed%20will%20drive%20you%20up%20the%20wall Driving a racing car at an angle of 90 degrees to the ground could be possible with the right track design, suggests student paper A group of four MPhys physics students from the Department of Physics and Astronomy have worked out that a racing car travelling at over 150 miles per hour would be able to stick to the walls of a completely circular speedway track with 90 degree banks - but don't\ufffd\ufffdbe tempted to give it a try next time you are stuck in traffic.

At speeds of 150mph, the force of gravity acting on a racing car would be less than the frictional force holding the car on the wall, meaning the car would easily be able to stay on the vertical banking.

The students published their findings in a final year paper for the Journal of Physics Special Topics, a peer-reviewed student journal run by the Department.

  • Press Release

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Physics Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff 2014-03-12T12:10:00Z Blog Entry \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdDon\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt pull that!\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd University of Leicester physics students investigate Bond ejector seat https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/201cdon2019t-pull-that-201d-university-of-leicester-physics-students-investigate-bond-ejector-seat Four-year Master of Physics students examine famous seat from Goldfinger Master\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds students at the University of Leicester's Department of Physics and Astronomy have explored the feasibility of James Bond\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds DB5 ejector seat from Goldfinger: That is, the one Bond uses to get rid of unwanted passengers. Could this ever be a real feature of modern cars - as an optional extra, of course?

To find out, the team first studied the trajectory of the ejected\ufffd\ufffdhenchman in the film footage. They worked out the highest point the henchmen reached when ejected from the seat by measuring the pixels in the screenshots and comparing against the known height of the car. Using the maximum height of 2.37 m the team then modelled the motion of the ejected henchman.\ufffd\ufffd For all of you budding (or actual) secret agents out there, all you need to eject your typical henchman through the sunroof of an Aston Martin DB5 is a force of 1930 N and 8870 Pa respectively, exerted as a constant force via a hydraulic piston

Their paper, No Mr Bond, I Expect You To Drive, was published in the latest volume of the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Journal of Physics Special Topics. The journal is published every year, and features original short papers written by students as part of their four-year Master of Physics degree \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and encourages students to think creatively, adopting off-the-wall topics. Still, no Aston Martin \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdVanish\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd just yet \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the team found an invisible car was, sadly, not yet a possibility.

  • Read the press release
]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Student Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff Physics 2013-07-03T10:25:39Z Blog Entry \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2.9 million project provides platform for PhD students to pursue innovative research https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/november/20ac2-9-million-project-provides-platform-for-phd-students-to-pursue-innovative-research Launch of INTREPID Forensics at annual Forensic Sciences Conference The Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences held its annual conference at College Court, the University's conference centre and hotel, on 7-8 November and during the event officially launched the Interdisciplinary Training and Research Programme for Innovative Doctorates in Forensic Science (INTREPID Forensics).

INTREPID Forensics is a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2.9 million multidisciplinary project funded by the People Programme of the European Union\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Seventh Framework Programme and provides funding for 10 early stage researchers to pursue innovative research degrees focussing on areas applicable to the forensic sciences.

The project received nearly 300 applications from 58 different countries. The researchers will investigate forensic technologies with the potential to impact crime across Europe and globally.

The research projects are all based at the University of Leicester and are co-supervised by academics in a wide range of disciplines including Genetics, Criminology, Chemistry, Psychology, Engineering, Mathematics, Physics, Pathology and Immunity, Infection and Inflammation.

Dr Lisa Smith, INTREPID Forensics Project Coordinator and senior lecturer in the Department of Criminology, said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences conference and postgraduate symposium was the perfect event for the launch of the INTREPID Forensics project. It provided a great opportunity for the ten PhD researchers on the INTREPID project to network with other postgraduate students and industry experts, as well as raising awareness of the project within the wider forensic community.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Dr Anya Hunt, CEO of the Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences, added: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences were delighted to host their annual Autumn conference and AGM at College Court in Leicester this year. In the 30th anniversary year since the DNA profiling discovery at the University of Leicester, and with the launch if the INTREPID Forensics project, it was an opportunity not to be missed. The Society\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds trace evidence conference and parallel post graduate research symposium, organised in conjunction with Dr. Lisa Smith, were both a huge success. We look forward to seeing the INTREPID project develop and we hope to see the student present their findings at future events.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The conference, held at College Court, focused on the theme of trace evidence and attracted academics and practitioners from across the forensic sciences. There was also a Postgraduate Symposium which featured student research presentations from universities all over the UK and across a wide range of forensic disciplines.\ufffd\ufffd

All of the INTREPID Forensics researchers are writing research blogs about their experiences over the next three years. People can subscribe to the blogs by visiting the project website.

]]> No publisher ap507 Chemistry Psychology Genetics pathology Engineering Criminology Infection, Immunity and Inflammation Physics Mathematics 2014-11-18T11:40:00Z Blog Entry
